content.webTitle: Australian federal police raid Labor senator's office over alleged NBN leaks

fields.headline: Australian federal police raid Labor senator's office over alleged NBN leaks
fields.bodyText: The Australian federal police has revealed it was NBN Co that asked it to investigate the alleged leaking of confidential documents. The AFP confirmed it executed two search warrants in Melbourne on Thursday night over allegations of unauthorised leaking of confidential National Broadband Network documents. It said NBN Co referred the matter to the AFP on 9 December, and the investigation has been ongoing since then. The AFP statement on Friday said the investigation had been undertaken “independent of government” and that decisions regarding the raids were made “by the AFP alone”. The parliamentary offices of Labor senator Stephen Conroy in Melbourne and a house on Allan Street in the Melbourne suburb of Brunswick, which is believed to be the home of a staffer for Labor’s communication spokesman, Jason Clare, were raided on Thursday night. It is also understood another Labor staffer is also named on the warrant. At least five plain clothes officers, in two separate cars, were waiting in the street outside the Brunswick address from 8pm. They knocked on the door within moments of four people, presumed to include the resident of the house, arriving at the property. By 11.30pm, 10 police officers, many pulling document suitcases, had entered the house. Two officers strung a sheet across an uncovered front window after television cameras captured them apparently conducting a search in that room. Seven of the officers emerged from cars that had been parked on the street for several hours. Both AFP officers and residents of the house have so far declined to comment. Fairfax Media has reported that up to 20 NBN Co employees are understood to have been interviewed by the AFP over the alleged leak. The Labor leader, Bill Shorten, said the raids were an “an extraordinary development” and relate to the time when the prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, was communications minister. Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese said on Friday morning it was “quite extraordinary” that the AFP left one staffer’s home just half an hour earlier. “What that means is that it has been quite an extraordinary raid, over an extensive period of time, in extraordinary circumstances during an election campaign,” he told the Nine Network. Cabinet minister Christopher Pyne said the government found out about the raids after they began. Pyne accused Labor of trying to politicise the AFP investigation. The idea that the AFP would time its raid on Senator Conroy’s office and Labor staffers was “nothing short of loopy”, Pyne said. “If you are suggesting that the government has organised raids by the AFP against the Labor party, that is an extraordinary allegation,” he said. Albanese hit back at claims Labor was politicising the issue, insisting he found out raids were happening during the footy. “What we saw was the media notified in advance; in advance of the people themselves being notified.” He said Turnbull was “very precious” about what happened to NBN Co under his watch when he was communications minister. “Malcolm Turnbull has to state exactly what his involvement in this is, given particularly that it relates to, frankly, facts that the public have a right to know about the National Broadband Network and the fact he has turned it into fraud-band.” “We know that he was desperate to stop it getting out that the roll-out is way behind time,” Albanese said. He said the timing of the raids was unprecedented and extraordinary, but insisted Senator Conroy and the two staffers had nothing to hide. He questioned why there weren’t similar investigations into leaks of cabinet documents ahead of the 3 May budget. Pyne accused Labor of attacking the AFP instead of co-operating with the investigation and doing the right thing. “The truth is the government had nothing to do with it.” He said there were investigations into cabinet leaks but refused to specify which ones, insisting referrals made to the AFP were a matter for police, not political parties. The shadow attorney general, Mark Dreyfus, said the raids were “unprecedented”. “We have never witnessed such an extraordinary action during a federal election campaign,” he said in a statement. “What we also know is that there have been other serious leaks out of government – including relating to national security, defence and the federal budget – and none of them have resulted in federal police raids.” Turnbull told reporters on Thursday evening it was a matter for the AFP. Labor frontbencher Tony Burke told ABC’s 7.30 program that there were allegations “floating around” about documents being leaked from NBN Co before the raids. “There’s no doubt the leaks that came from the NBN caused immense damage, immense damage to Malcolm Turnbull when they showed the cost blowout of the NBN, the fact it was slower and going to be delayed,” Burke said. “The thing that I also know with this is during the life of this parliament, on 23 different occasions we’ve asked about leaks from all parts of this government, right through to the national security committee of cabinet. “The night before the budget government staffers were handing out cabinet-in-confidence documents around the press gallery. I know how many of those inquiries have resulted in police raids. I don’t know how many times they’ve been referred to the AFP.” The AFP said Thursday’s raids in East Melbourne and Brunswick were part of a phased approach toward the investigation, with the next phase involving examination and analysis of material collected during the raids. “The federal government and opposition were appropriately notified and advised of operational activity regarding this matter after it commenced yesterday,” it said. It said it received assistance from NBN Co, including interviews with employees as part of the raids. • Australian Associated Press contributed to this report
